race.name: Rule of Three
race.tagline: 300 miles on Unbound roads—Kansas Flint Hills ultra distance, self-supported, 30-40% DNF, 15-25 hours of suffering.

vitals.location: Emporia, Kansas (same roads as Unbound Gravel)

climate.description: Early September: 60-85°F, 20% rain chance, late summer heat.

terrain.primary: Kansas Flint Hills—same roads as Unbound, ultra distance
terrain.surface: 95% gravel, 5% pavement. Kansas Flint Hills—same roads as Unbound Gravel. Relentless rolling terrain. 300 miles = 15-25 hours. 15,000 ft cumulative elevation. Technical rating: 2/5 (not technical, but ultra distance).

biased_opinion.summary: Rule of Three is 300 miles on Unbound roads. Same Kansas Flint Hills rollers, but 3x the distance. Founded ~2018. Ultra distance (15-25 hours). Self-supported (aid stations but no SAG). ~100 riders. 30-40% DNF. Early September late summer heat (60-85°F). If you want ultra distance suffering on Unbound roads, this is it. If you want manageable distance or beginner-friendly, skip it. 300 miles is brutal. Mental game critical.
strengths: Same roads as Unbound (iconic Flint Hills)
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Rule of Three is 300 miles on Unbound roads. If you want ultra distance suffering on iconic Flint Hills, this is it. If you want manageable distance or technical terrain, skip it. 30-40% DNF. 15-25 hours. Mental game critical. Self-supported. Brutal but unique.

logistics.lodging_note: Emporia small town (same as Unbound). Book early.
logistics.travel_summary: Wichita airport 90 miles. Rental car needed. Emporia small town—book lodging early. Day-before packet pickup. Race early September.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course (self-supported—no SAG). Post-race party if you finish.
logistics.camping: Camping on-site at event location (gorgeous open field for tents, no RVs/camper vans on field

course_description.character: 300 miles, 15,000 ft. 95% gravel, 5% pavement. Kansas Flint Hills—same roads as Unbound. Ultra distance (15-25 hours). Technical rating: 2/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Flint Hills Relentless Rollers
suffering_zones.description: Relentless rolling terrain. Never stops. Cumulative fatigue. 15,000 ft over 300mi.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Pace conservatively. Low gears. Mental game critical. 15-25 hours long.

suffering_zones.name: Mile 200+: Mental Breakdown Zone
suffering_zones.description: 100 miles to go. Legs gone. Mental game critical. 30-40% DNF here.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Break into chunks. Focus on next aid station. Mental toughness.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Self-Supported
suffering_zones.description: Aid stations but no SAG. Mechanicals = DNF. Carry spares, tools, lights.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Carry spares, CO2, multitool, dynamo lights. Self-sufficient.

course_description.signature_challenge: 300 miles ultra distance. Flint Hills rollers never stop. 15-25 hours. 30-40% DNF.

history.founder: Rule of Three LLC (USA Cycling Permit #8338)
history.origin_story: Rule of Three founded ~2018. 300 miles on Unbound roads. Kansas Flint Hills. Ultra distance. Self-supported. ~100 riders. Emporia same town as Unbound.
history.reputation: Ultra distance on Unbound roads. 300mi. 30-40% DNF. Self-supported. Brutal.

logistics.explanation: Completely self-supported navigation on unmarked trails through three surfaces. Teams must stay together at designated checkpoints. Andy Chasteen built community decision-making into the event—during COVID, he put cancellation to a Facebook vote, got 80/20 in favor of canceling, and refunded all fees.

length.explanation: The 300-mile distance across Emporia's roads creates sustained suffering over mixed terrain. Team racing option allows groups of three to tackle the distance together, departing in time trial intervals. Chasteen notes the team format "creates a lower barrier of intimidation" for riders too intimidated to attempt 100+ miles solo. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: Andy Chasteen describes the singletrack as "not super techy, it's pretty smooth, fast, and flowy, but very climby." The course breaks down to 30 miles pavement, 50 miles gravel, 20 miles singletrack. Technical challenge comes from surface transitions rather than features—riders debate hardtail versus gravel setups for optimal speed. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 15,000 feet over 300 miles creates relentless climbing rather than dramatic peaks. Chasteen notes the singletrack sections are "very climby" with the kind that leaves "your mouth hurting because you've been smiling the whole time." The elevation accumulates steadily across all three surface types. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 83°F and lows of 63°F, with a 23% chance of rain on any given day. Weather varies dramatically from year to year across the extended distance. The 300-mile format means experiencing whatever conditions develop over the full day and potentially into night. Kansas spring weather can shift from rain to heat over the long hours required to complete the course. Milder conditions than Crusher in the Tushar.

altitude.explanation: Emporia sits around 1,100 feet elevation. Zero altitude impact on performance for riders from anywhere above sea level. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Andy Chasteen's multi-surface concept emerged while testing bikes in Bentonville: "on this bike we could ride singletrack, gravel, and road all day long." The race starts and ends at Coler Mountain Bike Preserve with "flowy jump lines and techy rock sections," potentially "finishing on the dual slalom course."

prestige.explanation: Chasteen draws inspiration from Burning Man culture: "It's very Burning Man-esque with costumes and quirky weirdness." The event includes oddball categories like "Most selfies with roadkill" with Enve wheels as prizes. Philosophy remains "This event will never be about making a living, it will always about making a cool event."

race_quality.explanation: Self-supported format with unmarked courses creates pure adventure racing conditions. Chasteen keeps entry fees at $60-65 and requires sponsors to "come and do something that creates value for the people at the event" rather than just providing cash. Quality depends entirely on rider preparation and navigation skills.

experience.explanation: The multi-surface format delivers unique variety requiring equipment strategy and surface adaptation. Chasteen's Burning Man influence shows in costumes and quirky categories. The event emphasizes community participation through team options and post-race gathering at the preserve with its technical mountain bike features.

community.explanation: Chasteen puts major decisions to Facebook votes, creating "buy-in for people who come to your event." The philosophy centers on "fewer dollars, more community" with sponsors required to add value through experiences rather than cash. Team format encourages group participation and shared suffering across the distance.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of ~100 riders (ultra distance, limited field), team format creates accessibility for riders intimidated by solo ultra-distance racing. Chasteen notes teams departing in time trial style after solo racers, with checkpoint requirements keeping groups together. The quirky categories and Burning Man atmosphere attract participants focused on experience over pure competition. Similar competitive depth to The Rift.

value.explanation: Entry fees kept deliberately low at $60-65 range according to Chasteen's community-first philosophy. Sponsors provide experiential value like after-parties rather than cash prizes. The 30+ pound bike category and roadkill selfie contests with quality prizes like Enve wheels add entertainment value beyond pure racing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $200-$250. Andy Chasteen warns about tire durability: "The rock is sharp, too, so you're gonna have to run durable tires or you're gonna slash a sidewall." Equipment strategy varies significantly—"A hardtail rigid mountain bike on 2.0 tires might win this. Or an Able with 650b wheels and 50mm tires." Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: Three hundred miles on Unbound roads without the Unbound circus—just you, Kansas, and the kind of suffering that builds character.
final_verdict.should_you_race: This is for riders who want the full Unbound experience without paying Unbound prices or fighting Unbound crowds. You need legitimate endurance fitness—300 miles doesn't negotiate, and the self-supported nature means your mistakes compound quickly. Come prepared for mental warfare disguised as a bike race.
final_verdict.alternatives: Unbound 200 gives you the same roads with aid stations and more prestige, while Mid South offers similar distance with better terrain variety and actual community vibe. If you want the suffering without the Kansas wind penalty, Crusher in the Tushar delivers mountain punishment instead of prairie monotony.

unsplash_photos.description: a bunch of rocks that are laying on the ground
A pile of small, gray and tan gravel stones.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

primary.name: Continental Terra Trail
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces. excellent wet grip

primary.name: Goodyear Connector
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
